data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: We will recruit 2,000 participants from MTurk. Based on previous MTurk surveys, we expect that this will yield approximately 1,500 Whites and 125-150 Blacks.

analyses.value: We will conduct two separate two-proportions z-tests to compare openness to going vegetarian and vegan between Whites and Blacks. An effect is considered to be significant if it yields a p-value of less than .05.

outliers.value: Participants will be excluded from analyses if they indicate that they are vegetarian/vegan, indicate that they are neither White nor Black, fail an attention check in the survey, or enter that they are either an unpermitted (<18 years) or an impossible (>117 years) age.

dependent.value:
Openness to going vegetarian will be assessed by the question, “Do you plan on becoming a vegetarian at any upcoming point in your life?” to which responses will include “no,” “maybe,” and “yes.” Participants who respond “no” will be classified as not open to going vegetarian, whereas participants who respond either “maybe” or “yes” will be classified as open to going vegetarian.

Openness to going vegan will be assessed in the same manner as openness to going vegetarian, but with the word “vegan” in place of “vegetarian.”

The first independent variable for this study is race, which will be assessed by the question, “Which race/ethnicity best describes you?” to which responses will include “White / Caucasian,” “Black / African American,” “Hispanic or Latinx,” “Asian or Pacific Islander,” “Native American,” or “Other.” Participants who select the response “White / Caucasian” will be coded as White and participants who select the response “Black / African American” will be coded as Black.

conditions.value: There are no conditions in this survey; all participants will complete the same survey.

hypothesis.value: The purpose of this study is to investigate whether openness to going vegetarian and vegan differs between Whites and Blacks. We hypothesize that Blacks will be more open to going vegetarian and vegan than Whites will be.

attributes.title: Race and Vegetarianism Associations and Belongingness

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Race and Vegetarianism Associations and Belongingness

sample.value: We will recruit 2,000 participants from MTurk. Based on previous MTurk surveys, we expect that this will yield approximately 1,500 Whites and 125-150 Blacks.

analyses.value: We will conduct an ordinary least squares multiple regression to test for an interaction effect between participant race and explicit association on belongingness. We will regress belongingness on participant race, explicit association, and the interaction term for participant race and explicit association. If this interaction effect is significant, then we will follow up by regressing belongingness on explicit association within each racial group separately. An effect is considered to be significant if it yields a p-value of less than .05.

outliers.value: Participants will be excluded from analyses if they indicate that they are vegetarian/vegan, indicate that they are neither White nor Black, or fail an attention check in the survey, or enter that they are either an unpermitted (<18 years) or an impossible (>117 years) age.

dependent.value:
The dependent variable of this study is the degree to which one feels that one would belong in the vegetarian community. Feelings of belongingness in the vegetarian community will be assessed using an adapted 8-item version of Malone et al.’s (2012) General Belongingness Scale. The scale will begin with a prompt that reads, “If I were to become a vegetarian…” and will follow with 8 items on separate lines below, each presenting a Likert-type response scale. These items include “I would feel included by other vegetarians,” “I would feel a sense of belonging in the vegetarian community,” “I would feel close bonds with other vegetarians,” “I would feel accepted by other vegetarians,” “I would feel connected with other vegetarians,” “I would feel like an outsider from other vegetarians” (reverse-scored), “I would feel distant from other vegetarians” (reverse-scored), “I would feel like a stranger around other vegetarians” (reverse-scored). Responses will range from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

The first independent variable for this study is race, which will be assessed by the question, “Which race/ethnicity best describes you?” to which responses will include “White / Caucasian,” “Black / African American,” “Hispanic or Latinx,” “Asian or Pacific Islander,” “Native American,” or “Other.” Participants who select the response “White / Caucasian” will be coded as White and participants who select the response “Black / African American” will be coded as Black.

The second independent variable is explicit association between race and vegetarianism, which will be assessed using four total items. The first two items will lead with the following prompt: “Please bring to mind people who eat a vegetarian diet. In your mind, how “vegetarian” are people who belong to the following racial groups? That is, how strongly are they identified with vegetarianism and all things vegetarian?” and will follow with two items on separate lines below, each presenting a Likert-type scale. The item on the first line will read “White people” and on the second line “Black people.” Responses to each of these two items will range from 1 (not at all) to 5 (very much). We will subtract each participant’s score on the second item from their score on the first item in order to compute a score capturing the extent of association of vegetarianism as White over Black. The next two items will lead with the question, “When you think of a vegetarian, how much do you think of someone who is …?” and will follow with two items on separate lines below, each presenting a Likert-type scale. The item on the first line will read “White” and on the second line “Black.” Responses to each of these two items will range from 1 (not at all) to 5 (very much). We will subtract each participant’s score on the second item from their score on the first item in order to compute a score to reflect the extents of association of vegetarianism as White over Black. We will compute an average of these two computed association scores to arrive at a final variable that will operationalize explicit association of vegetarianism with Whites over Blacks.

conditions.value: There are no conditions in this survey; all participants will complete the same survey.

hypothesis.value: The purpose of this study is to investigate whether the link between explicit race-vegetarian associations and feelings of belongingness in the vegetarian community differs between Whites and Blacks. We hypothesize an interaction effect between participant race and race-vegetarian association on belongingness, such that association of vegetarianism as White over Black will negatively predict belongingness among Blacks but offer either null or positive predictive value among Whites.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: We will recruit 2,000 participants. We will set Qualtrics to randomly present participants with one of the four conditions. Thus, we expect to recruit approximately 500 participants in each condition.

analyses.value: First, we will conduct a one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) to test whether there is an effect of framing condition on willingness to make dietary change. An effect is considered to be significant if it yields a p-value of less than .05. Second, we will conduct all six possible pairwise comparisons within this ANOVA to test, specifically, which of these four conditions differ from one another. We will evaluate each of the comparisons of plant-based versus meatless and vegetarian versus vegan at a significance threshold of p = .05, as we set hypotheses for these two tests a priori. We will evaluate each of the other four pairwise comparisons (plant-based vs. vegetarian, plant-based vs. vegan, meatless vs. vegetarian, and meatless vs. vegan) at a Bonferroni-adjusted significance threshold of p = .012.

outliers.value: Participants will be excluded from analyses if they indicate that they are vegetarian/vegan, fail an attention check in the survey, or enter that they are either an unpermitted (<18 years) or an impossible (>117 years) age.

dependent.value: The key dependent variable is willingness to make dietary change. This variable’s operationalization will across the four framing conditions will be inherent to how the wording of each condition’s scale items is manipulated. Willingness to make dietary change will be assessed by the following 3-item scale template across all conditions, with the word “[frame]” serving as a placeholder that will differ by condition. This scale will lead with the question, “How willing are you to…” and on the following lines will be these three items: “eat more [frame] meals?,” “cook more [frame] meals?,” and “order more [frame] meals at restaurants?” In the plant-based condition, “[frame]” will be replaced with “plant-based” (e.g., eat more plant-based meals?); in the meatless condition, “[frame]” will be replaced with “meatless”; in the vegetarian condition, “[frame]” will be replaced with “vegetarian”; and in the vegan condition, “[frame]” will be replaced with “vegan.” Responses to items will range from 1 (very unwilling) to 7 (very willing).

conditions.value: This study involves four conditions: plant-based, meatless, vegetarian, and vegan. Participants will be assigned to one of these conditions at random.

hypothesis.value: We are testing whether meat-eaters are differentially willing to make more plant-based food choices depending on how those food choices are framed. We will examine four ways of framing plant-based food choices: describing them as (1) plant-based, (2) meatless, (3) vegetarian, or (4) vegan. First, we hypothesize that participants will be more willing to make food choices that are framed as “plant-based” compared to food choices framed as “meatless.” Second, we hypothesize that participants will be more willing to make food choices that are framed as “vegetarian” compared to food choices framed as “vegan.” We set no directional hypotheses for each of the other possible four pairwise comparisons between these framing conditions.

attributes.title: Gender Roles, Disgust, and Food Frequency

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Gender Roles, Disgust, and Food Frequency

analyses.value:
First, we will create median splits for each of the 4 gender role variables, as to identify which participants score high versus low on each. Then, for each of the 8 foods, we will conduct the following analysis to test whether the gender difference in the disgust-consumption link—such that the correlation between disgust toward a food and frequency of consuming that food is stronger (i.e., more negative) for women than for men—is larger among participants who endorse gender roles more strongly than among those who endorse gender roles weakly.

The set of equations below outlines steps for computing the difference in difference in correlation coefficients in R. r1 represents the correlation between disgust and consumption for “low gender role” men; r2 for “low gender role” women; r3 “high gender role” women; and r4 for “high gender role” men. n1 represents the sample size for “low gender role” men; n2 for “low gender role” women; n3 “high gender role” women; and n4 for “high gender role” men. Each z value represents the z value for each r, derived from Fisher’s transformation. Z represents the z-score for the difference in difference in correlation coefficients, which is then used to compute a p-value. An effect is considered to be significant if it yields a p-value of less than .05.

z1 = 0.5*log((1+r1)/(1-r1))
z2 = 0.5*log((1+r2)/(1-r2))
z3 = 0.5*log((1+r3)/(1-r3))
z4 = 0.5*log((1+r4)/(1-r4))
se = ((1/(n1-3))+(1/(n2-3))+(1/(n3-3))+(1/(n4-3)))^0.5
Z = ((z3-z4)-(z2-z1))/se
Z
p = 2*pnorm(-abs(Z))
p

outliers.value: Participants will be excluded from analyses if they fail an attention check in the survey, report a non-binary gender identity status, or enter that they are either an unpermitted (<18 years) or an impossible (>117 years) age.

dependent.value:
Specific to each of the 8 foods, we are assessing 1 dependent variable (consumption frequency) and 1 independent variable (disgust). Gender role variables to be assessed are gender identity centrality, self-ascribed masculinity/femininity, endorsement of prescriptive stereotypes about one's own gender, and endorsement of gender roles in eating.

Our 8 dependent variables are consumption frequency of fish, pork, oatmeal, tofu, soda, chicken, beef, and coffee. Each of these variables will be assessed by its own question, which will follow the following structure, with “[food]” serving as a placeholder for each of the 8 foods to be assessed: “How often do you eat [food]?” with responses (and how they will be scored in parentheses; not shown to participants) including never (1), a few times per year (2), once per month (3), a few times per month (4), once per week (5), 2 to 3 days per week (6), 4 to 6 days per week (7), 1 meal per day (8), 2 meals per day (9), and 3 or more meals per day (10). For example, for beef, this question will read, “How often do you eat beef?” For coffee and soda this question will read, “drink” instead of “eat,” and the 8th, 9th, and 10th responses will read, “cup(s) per day” instead of “meal(s) per day.”

Our 8 disgust independent variables are disgust toward fish, pork, oatmeal, tofu, soda, chicken, beef, and coffee. Each of these variables will be assessed by its own set of 3 items, which will follow the following structure, with “[food]” serving as a placeholder for each of the 8 foods to be assessed: “[Food] is disgusting,” “The thought of eating [food] makes me nauseous,” and “[Food] is gross,” measured via a scale of 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree). For example, for beef, these items will read, “Beef is disgusting,” “The thought of eating beef makes me nauseous,” and “Beef is gross.” For coffee and soda, the second item will read, “drinking” instead of “eating.”

Gender will be assessed by the item, “Please select your gender,” with responses including “Man,” “Woman,” “Non-Binary,” and “Other.”

Gender identity centrality will be assessed by the following 4 items. Each item will read either “man” or “woman” depending on what participants indicate their own gender is. “I often think about the fact that I am a man/woman,” “Overall, being a man/woman has very little to do with how I feel about myself” (reverse-scored),” “In general, being a man/woman is an important part of my self-image,” and “The fact that I am a man/woman rarely enters my mind (reverse-scored).” Responses will range from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

Self-ascribed masculinity/femininity will be assessed by Kachel et al.’s (2016) traditional masculinity/femininity scale, which is comprised of the following 6 items: “I consider myself as…” “Ideally, I would like to be…” “Traditionally, my interests would be considered as…” “Traditionally, my attitudes and beliefs would be considered as…” “Traditionally, my behavior would be considered as…” and “Traditionally, my outer appearance would be considered as…” Responses will range from 1 (very feminine) to 7 (very masculine). This variable will be reverse-scored for women so that higher scores reflect greater alignment with gender roles for one’s own gender for all participants (i.e., higher femininity for women, higher masculinity for men).

Endorsement of prescriptive stereotypes about one's own gender (cleanliness=femininity association for women, risk-taking=masculinity association for men) will be assessed by 4 items. Participants will complete the association scale respective to their own gender, with women completing the cleanliness=femininity association and men completing the risk-taking=masculinity association. For women participants, the scale will lead with the following prompt: “Compared to men, women are expected to be more…” and will follow with 4 items on separate lines below, each presenting a Likert-type from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree): “clean,” “hygienic,” “sanitary,” and “pristine.” For men participants, the scale will lead with the following prompt: “Compared to women, men are expected to be more…” and will follow with 4 items on separate lines below, each presenting a Likert-type from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree): “risk-taking,” “brave,” “courageous,” and “adventurous.”

Endorsement of gender roles in eating will be assessed by 5 items. Participants will complete a scale of gender roles respective to their own gender. Women participants will complete the following items: “Women are expected to eat petite meals,” “Being a messy eater makes a woman seem less feminine,” “Women are judged negatively when they eat meals with poor table manners,” “Eating gross foods makes a woman seem less feminine,” and “Women are expected to have better table etiquette than men are.” Men participants will complete the following items: “Men are expected to eat hearty meals,” “Being a messy eater makes a man seem more masculine,” “Men are judged negatively when they eat meals with poor table manners” (reverse-scored), “Eating gross foods makes a man seem more masculine,” and “Men are expected to have worse table etiquette than women are.” Responses will range from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

conditions.value: There are no conditions in this survey; all participants will complete the same survey.

hypothesis.value: We have found previously that the correlation between disgust toward a food and frequency of consuming that food is stronger (i.e., more negative) for women than for men. In the current study, we hypothesize that this gender difference is amplified among participants who score high (compared to participants who score low) on the following 4 “gender role” variables: gender identity centrality, self-ascribed masculinity/femininity, endorsement of prescriptive stereotypes about one's own gender, and endorsement of gender roles in eating. We will test this overarching hypothesis across 8 foods: fish, pork, oatmeal, tofu, soda, chicken, beef, and coffee.  The reason for these 8 foods is that we found significant differences in the correlation between disgust and consumption frequency by gender for each of these foods in a prior completed study.

This variable will be reverse-scored for women so that higher scores reflect greater alignment with gender roles for one’s own gender for all participants (i.e., higher femininity for women, higher masculinity for men).

Endorsement of prescriptive stereotypes about one's own gender (cleanliness=femininity association for women, risk-taking=masculinity association for men) will be assessed by 4 items. Participants will complete the association scale respective to their own gender, with women completing the cleanliness=femininity association and men completing the risk-taking=masculinity association. For women participants, the scale will lead with the following prompt: “Compared to men, women are expected to be more…” and will follow with 4 items on separate lines below, each presenting a Likert-type from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree): “clean,” “hygienic,” “sanitary,” and “pristine.” For men participants, the scale will lead with the following prompt: “Compared to women, men are expected to be more…” and will follow with 4 items on separate lines below, each presenting a Likert-type from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree): “risk-taking,” “brave,” “courageous,” and “adventurous.”

Endorsement of gender roles in eating will be assessed by 5 items. Participants will complete a scale of gender roles respective to their own gender. Women participants will complete the following items: “Women are expected to eat petite meals,” “Being a messy eater makes a woman seem less feminine,” “Women are judged negatively when they eat meals with poor table manners,” “Eating gross foods makes a woman seem less feminine,” and “Women are expected to have better table etiquette than men are.” Men participants will complete the following items: “Men are expected to eat hearty meals,” “Being a messy eater makes a man seem more masculine,” “Men are judged negatively when they eat meals with poor table manners” (reverse-scored), “Eating gross foods makes a man seem more masculine,” and “Men are expected to have worse table etiquette than women are.” Responses will range from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).
registration_responses.conditions: There are no conditions in this survey; all participants will complete the same survey.
registration_responses.hypothesis: We have found previously that the correlation between disgust toward a food and frequency of consuming that food is stronger (i.e., more negative) for women than for men. In the current study, we hypothesize that this gender difference is amplified among participants who score high (compared to participants who score low) on the following 4 “gender role” variables: gender identity centrality, self-ascribed masculinity/femininity, endorsement of prescriptive stereotypes about one's own gender, and endorsement of gender roles in eating. We will test this overarching hypothesis across 8 foods: fish, pork, oatmeal, tofu, soda, chicken, beef, and coffee.  The reason for these 8 foods is that we found significant differences in the correlation between disgust and consumption frequency by gender for each of these foods in a prior completed study.

comments.value:
Previous studies examining how people extract structure from their environments (commonly called “Statistical Learning”) have shown that the statistical structure of the environment affects how learners allocate their attention: Infants selectively attend to parts of their input that are neither highly predictable nor highly unpredictable (Kidd, Piantadosi, & Aslin, 2012), and adults allocate attention to regular rather than irregular sequences (Zhao, Al-Aidroos, & Turk-Browne, 2013). This raises two questions, which are the focus of the current project: (1) Do children and adults show different attention allocation profiles in response to the structure of the environment such that children show a stronger preference than adults do to preferentially attend to more or less predictable aspects of their environment, and (2) How does attention allocation vary across learners (within age group), and what are the relations between individual differences in attention allocation and learning outcomes.
This is a follow-up preregistration to a nearly identical preregistration submitted for an earlier version of this project. The exposure phase described below will be identical to the previous version. The test phase will the differ slightly, as described below.

This study and the previous version of this study address the question of “How does attention allocation vary across learners?” and focuses on adult learners. We will use a modified version of the paradigm introduced by Zhao et al. (2013). Four statistical streams each constructed from four pairs of stimuli will be presented simultaneously in four locations on the screen (at a rate of 1 shape from each stream/sec). Each stream will be characterized by different levels of predictability/information quantity: A random stream (Rate of information = 0.9bits), a highly unpredictable stream (4 pairs with within-pair transitional probabilities (TPs) = 0.4; Rate of information = 0.68), a semi-predictable stream (4 pairs with within-pair TPs = 0.8; Rate of information = 0.48), and a fully predictable stream (4 pairs with within-pair TPs = 1; Rate of information = 0.3; note: all Rate of information are calculated using log10). Each stream will consist of 60 repetitions of each pair (8 shapes*60 rep = 480 shapes per stream overall). 
As in Zhao et al., we will use a visual search task to examine attention allocation. Every 5 trials on average (with a range from 3 non-search trials to 8 non-search trials, with 96 search trials overall, 24 per location) a search trial will appear in place of another set of shapes from the four streams (and in the same locations as the streams), and the subject will have to identify a unique item from the 4 presented options. We will adapt the Zhao et al task slightly, such that the search task will change from asking participants to indicate the direction of the tail of a “T” character amongst “L” characters, to asking participants to indicate whether the stem of a four-leaf clover (amongst three-leaf clovers) was a line or a circle. 
We will also track participants eye movements during the course of exposure to get additional measures (fixations to each stream, looking away probability) of what participants were attending to on each of the learning trials. 

After the exposure and search task, participants will complete a second, novel, statistical learning exposure phase of a totally new structure of different objects. Then, after watching these shapes, they will complete a test with both alternative-forced-choice (AFC) trials and pattern recognition trials to assess learning of that new stream. The design of this task will be based on Siegelman et al. 2017.  

We will run a total of 48 adult subjects, from the University of Toronto subject pool. This number was chosen based off the results of a power analysis using data previously collected in the same design (without eye tracking – based only on the search task data). We used those data to carry out a sensitivity analysis of the interaction between entropy and trial (post-hoc power from that experiment (n = 75) was 1.0). Then, to calculate the number of participants we would need for 90% power in the study described here, we randomly sampled a subset of our participants across a range of sample sizes (n = 10-75) and carried out a new sensitivity analysis at each sample size (total of 1000 bootstrapped iterations at each N). This gave us an expected power value at each sample size from 10-75, which allowed us to determine that after about 35 participants we will continuously be above 90% power. Because our design involves counterbalancing the location of each predictability level, we chose a sample size of 48 to ensure the same number of participants in each counterbalance. 
To ensure our participants are paying attention to our task and following instructions, we will not include participants who fail to respond correctly to 80% or more of the search trials. We also will not include participants for whom the eye tracker fails to collect reliable data (completely missing data on more than 25% of trials). These subjects will be replaced with additional participants until we have collected useable data from 48 people.

Data pre-processing and outlier removal: Prior to all analysis, RTs in the search trials will be log-transformed. Trials in which log-RTs are 2 SDs slower/faster from the subject mean will be removed. Fixations shorter than 80msec will be excluded from the analysis. Remaining fixation durations will be log-transformed and an identical outlier removal procedure to the one of search trials RT will be applied (cutoff: mean+-2SD).

Variables and analysis: 
1.	Effect of rate of information on attention allocation: here we will examine the relation between rate of information and mean RTs in the search trials. First, we will run a mixed effect model to see whether there is a significant effect of condition/rate of information on search trials RT. A significant effect of condition on search trials response latencies will be interpreted as evidence for learning – differential attention allocation behavior to streams with different information quantity.  We will then further examine the shape of the RT by rate of information function (whether it shows a U-shape function, as suggested by Kidd et al, or another consistent curvature). Since we only have 4 conditions, examination of the exact shape will not be based on comparison of linear/non-linear models. Instead, we will compare all pairs of conditions to one another (using contrasts in mixed models) to see what is the rank-order of the different conditions and what is conditions have significant faster/slower responses than others. Parallel models will be used to examine the effect of rate of information on fixation duration and looking away probabilities. 
2.	Attention allocation across time: Here we will examine whether attention allocation shifts over time to less/more predictable locations. To do so we will run a mixed effect model analysis predicting search task RTs from trial number, rate of information, and their interaction. We predict a significant interaction, again to be interpreted as evidence for learning that each location includes a different level of structure – differential attention allocation over time as a function of the information to be processed from the stream. We will explore contrasts of this interaction (i.e., whether over time participants attend more/less to more/less predictable streams). Again, parallel models will be used with the same predictors but with fixation durations and looking away probabilities as dependent variables.  
3.	Modeling information extraction across time: To further explore changes in attention allocation across time, we will continuously quantify the amount of information in each of the four streams at each point during exposure. This will be based on a continuous entropy estimation at each step based on the items presented in each of the four streams. The rationale behind this analysis is that during the exposure phase participants do not have access yet to the overall rate of information at each stream; instead, they can only rely on the stimuli that they actually observed up until each time point. We will therefore use this "continuous entropy" measure as a predictor in the models in (2) (replacing the overall rate of information in the stream), examining its effect on both search trials RT and fixation durations, and its interaction with trial number. This will test for differential attention allocation over time as a function of the amount of information available in each stream at each time point. 
4.	Basic analysis of statistical learning performance: As a first step, we will examine whether there is a significant learning effect in the second statistical learning task at the group-level (using t-tests comparing mean performance on the Alternative Force Choice and pattern completion tests to chance). We expect to find significant group-level learning with substantial individual differences, in line with previous data on the same task (e.g. Siegelman, Bogaerts, & Frost, 2017).
5.	Group-level relation between attention allocation and learning: here we will examine whether subjects who were better learners relative to the group show a different attentional allocation profile than worse learners. To do so, we will median-split the performance of learners on the second statistical learning task. Good vs. Bad learners will then be included as a factor in the models described above to determine if learning qualifies the effect of rate of information or its interaction with time. 
 
References:
 
Kidd, C., Piantadosi, S. T., & Aslin, R. N. (2012). The Goldilocks effect: Human infants allocate attention to visual sequences that are neither too simple nor too complex. PLoS ONE, 7(5), 1–8. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0036399
Siegelman, N., Bogaerts, L., & Frost, R. (2017). Measuring individual differences in statistical learning: Current pitfalls and possible solutions. Behavior Research Methods, 49(2), 418–432. https://doi.org/10.3758/s13428-016-0719-z
Zhao, J., Al-Aidroos, N., & Turk-Browne, N. B. (2013). Attention Is Spontaneously Biased Toward Regularities. Psychological Science, 24(5), 667–677. https://doi.org/10.1177/0956797612460407

attributes.title: Knowledgeability, Contextual Numerals and Scalar Implicature

q1.value: Knowledgeability, Contextual Numerals and Scalar Implicature

q2.value: Zheng Zhang, Edward Gibson, Rachel Ryskin, Leon Bergen, Alexander Paunov

q3.value:
"Some of the books were interesting." is typically interpreted to mean that a non-zero number of books was interesting but NOT ALL of the books were interesting, because the speaker would have said "all" if they were all interesting. This is a case of scalar implicature. Goodman and Stuhlmüller (2013) showed that comprehenders make this type of inference when the speaker has full knowledge (e.g., the speaker has read all 3 books) but the inference is (partly) cancelled when the speaker’s knowledge is limited (e.g., the speaker has only read 2 of the 3 books).

Previous work has also found that the online processing of “some” is slowed down when the speaker uses numerals to refer to small sets in the same context (Degen and Tanenhaus, 2015). 

In the present work, we explore the interaction between the knowledgeability of the speaker and the existence of contextual numerals in the offline processing of scalar implicature. In particular, we ask whether the use of numerals in the same context can affect offline processing of scalar implicature, by making comprehenders more aware of the more natural  alternative labels (e.g., Two of the books were interesting).

q4.value: We predict that the knowledgeability effect reported by Goodman and Stuhlmuller (2013) should be reduced when the surrounding context contains numerals. In other words we predict a significant interaction between knowledge state (knowledgeability) of the speaker and presence v. absence of numbers in the experimental context.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
The factor "knowledgeability" is within subject and has 2 levels (full knowledge and partial knowledge). The factor "contextual numeral" is between subject and has 2 levels (with numerals and no numerals).
Each participant will receive 8 target trials (4 partial knowledge + 4 full knowledge) and 24 exposure trials.
Half of the participants will receive exposure trials with numerals, and the other half will receive exposure trials with no numerals.

q9.value: We will use Turkolizer software from Gibson, Piantadosi, and Fedorenko (2011) to randomly assign the trials to each participant.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited on Amazon.com’s Mechanical Turk and complete the experiment for $3 dollars payment. People who meet the requirements (1)–(4) are eligible to participate in the experiment. 
(1) IP address inside the U.S.A.
(2) Have completed more than 100 surveys on Mechanical Turk. 
(3) Approval rate over 95%. 
(4) They must not have participated in our similar experiments before.

q13.value:
We will collect data from 300 participants.
Each participant will receive 8 target trials (4 partial knowledge + 4 full knowledge) and 24 exposure trials.
150 participants will receive exposure trials with numerals, and 150 participants will receive exposure trials with no numerals.

q14.value:
In a previous version of this experiment, we collected data until we reached the sample size of 240 participants. 
In the current study, we will analyze the data from the participants who meet all the requirements listed as follows. 1) Participants' native language is English. 2) They have completed at least 87.5% of the possibility rating questions. 3) Their accuracy on confirmation questions is at least 87.5%. 4) They are from the USA.
Based on the previous data from a previous experiment, about 82% of the people who participated in the experiment could meet all the above requirements. Therefore, in order to keep the same sample size as in the previous experiment, we decide to recruit 300 participants this time. (240/0.82≈293)

question.value:
We manipulate the speaker's knowledgeability and the existence of contextual numerals. 
The variable "knowledgeability" is within subject and has 2 levels: partial knowledge or full knowledge. The variable "contextual numeral" is between subject and has 2 levels: with numerals and no numerals.
Each participant will receive 8 target trials (4 partial knowledge + 4 full knowledge) and 24 exposure trials (12 partial knowledge + 12 full knowledge ).
Half of the participants will receive exposure trials with numerals, and the other half will receive exposure trials with no numerals.

More details: 

Each trial given to the participant is composed of three parts: a picture, a short paragraph of text, and three questions. 
An example critical trial is given as follows.
First, a picture is shown to the participant. The picture consists of a character and 3 objects. In the full knowledge condition, 3 of the 3 objects are circled.
Then, a paragraph of text follows the picture. The text first names the speaker and describes the objects and the relevant property: “Letters to Laura's company almost always have checks inside. Today Laura needs to find out whether the above letters have checks inside.” 
Then it is followed by a speech act in which the speaker both declares the (sub)set of the objects he or she has observed and states that some objects have the property: “While pointing to the circled set of letters, Laura tells you, ‘I have now checked these letters and given what I saw, I can tell you that some of today's letters have checks inside.’ ” 
Last, the question phase consists of three questions. The function of the first two questions is to confirm the participant has read the materials carefully and fully understood what is going on in the given scenario. Thus, the first two questions have correct answers. For example: “Did Laura look at all of today's letters?” (correct answer: yes) “Did Laura say that some of today's letters have checks inside?” (correct answer: yes) The third question asks the participant the likelihood of all the objects having the property. The answer to this question is the dependent factor we would analyze. “Assuming that the speaker is providing an accurate description of his/her knowledge, how likely is it that all of today's letters have checks inside? Please provide a probability percentage: ____%”

How we manipulate the speaker’s knowledgeability: 
In the “full knowledge” trials,  x of the x objects are circled in the picture and the speaker says she has checked “these ...(objects)”, while pointing to the circled set of ...(objects). 
In the “partial knowledge” trials, y of the x objects (y

What we will examine is listeners’ interpretation of a statement in which "some" may or may not trigger scalar implicature. The critical question will be "Assuming that the speaker is providing an accurate description of his/her knowledge, how likely is it that all of xxx (items) have the yyy (property)? Please provide a probability percentage: __%" 
This dependent variable ranges from 0% to 100%. If a listener responds with a lower percentage, they are more committed to the “some but not all” reading of “some”, whereas if they respond with a higher percentage, they are more committed to the “some and possibly all” reading by (partially) cancelling the standard implicature of “some”.

Effects of speaker’s perceptual access ("knowledgeability") and contextual numerals on probability ratings will be assessed via linear mixed-effects regression using the lme4 package in R (Bates, Maechler, Bolker, & Walker, 2014).
The predictors are "knowledgeability" and "contextual numeral", as well as their interaction. The dependent variable is the rating of the likelihood of all the items having the property (participants' interpretation of scalar implicature).

q20.value: Knowledgeability and Numerals conditions will be sum coded (-0.5, 0.5).

q21.value: We will use the standard .05 alpha criterion for determining significance of the main effects and interaction.

q22.value: We will exclude the data from the participants 1) whose native language is not English, 2) who cannot finish more than 87.5% of the possibility rating questions, 3) whose accuracy on confirmation questions is less than 87.5%, 4) and who do not come from the USA.

q24.value:
As an alternative, we might also assess the same effects via Bayesian Regression using the brms package in R (Bürkner 2017, Carpenter et al. 2017). The predictors and the dependent variable remain the same as in lmer.
For the Bayesian Regression, we will fit a beta distribution to our data. We will transform 0% to 0.1% and 100% to 99.9%.

q25.value:
We ran four previous versions of this experiment. The link to the preregistration of the previous experiments are osf.io/v7fx2, osf.io/ujc3m, osf.io/93wbh and osf.io/768nx.
In the first experiment, we found a pattern suggesting there was an interaction between the knowledgeability and the existence of numerals. In the second experiment, we slightly changed the experiment design: we added 8 exposure trials in each contextual numerals condition, making the ratio of exposure trials to critical trials increase from 2:1 to 3:1. We expected the change could make the No Numerals vs. With Numerals manipulation more salient and the hypothesized effects stronger. The predicted results were significant. In the third experiment, we adjusted the experiment materials to remove a potential confounding factor. In the first and second experiment, we had some large numbers in the fillers (e.g., "Robert needs to check whether 12 windows are closed."), whereas in the target trials the numbers were all three (e.g., "Zach needs to check whether 3 of the tickets have won"). This difference between "large numbers" vs. "small numbers" could be a confounding factor. Thus, in the third experiment, we changed all the numbers in the fillers to 3, 4 or 5, in order to ensure that the predicted interaction results from the existence/absence of the numerals rather than the difference between “large numbers” and “small numbers”. The predicted interaction was not significant, but the main effect of numerals was significant. We thought this could result from the fact that there were still numerals in the “no numerals” condition to indicate the total number of the items (e.g., “Zach needs to check whether 3 of the tickets have won.”). In the fourth experiment, we changed the experiment materials to remove this potential confounding factor: we got rid of the numerals in the materials in the “no-numerals” condition and instead used pictures to indicate the total number of the items and how many of them the character has checked. In addition, we got rid of all the exposure trials and kept only the critical trials. We expected the picture version could show the predicted effects without the more salient manipulation brought about by the exposure trials. But the predicted effects were not significant.  We concluded that fillers are needed in order to see the main effect of "some" for partial knowledge vs. full knowledge.  Thus, in this current study, we added back all the exposure trials. Also, we adjusted the critical trials so that they were all identical across the two conditions. We now just have the critical trials (all without number words) within our two sets of exposure trials.

registration_responses.q1: Knowledgeability, Contextual Numerals and Scalar Implicature
registration_responses.q2: Zheng Zhang, Edward Gibson, Rachel Ryskin, Leon Bergen, Alexander Paunov
registration_responses.q3:
"Some of the books were interesting." is typically interpreted to mean that a non-zero number of books was interesting but NOT ALL of the books were interesting, because the speaker would have said "all" if they were all interesting. This is a case of scalar implicature. Goodman and Stuhlmüller (2013) showed that comprehenders make this type of inference when the speaker has full knowledge (e.g., the speaker has read all 3 books) but the inference is (partly) cancelled when the speaker’s knowledge is limited (e.g., the speaker has only read 2 of the 3 books).

Previous work has also found that the online processing of “some” is slowed down when the speaker uses numerals to refer to small sets in the same context (Degen and Tanenhaus, 2015). 

In the present work, we explore the interaction between the knowledgeability of the speaker and the existence of contextual numerals in the offline processing of scalar implicature. In particular, we ask whether the use of numerals in the same context can affect offline processing of scalar implicature, by making comprehenders more aware of the more natural  alternative labels (e.g., Two of the books were interesting).
registration_responses.q4: We predict that the knowledgeability effect reported by Goodman and Stuhlmuller (2013) should be reduced when the surrounding context contains numerals. In other words we predict a significant interaction between knowledge state (knowledgeability) of the speaker and presence v. absence of numbers in the experimental context.

Based on the previous data from a previous experiment, about 82% of the people who participated in the experiment could meet all the above requirements. Therefore, in order to keep the same sample size as in the previous experiment, we decide to recruit 300 participants this time. (240/0.82≈293)

registration_responses.q25:
We ran four previous versions of this experiment. The link to the preregistration of the previous experiments are osf.io/v7fx2, osf.io/ujc3m, osf.io/93wbh and osf.io/768nx.
In the first experiment, we found a pattern suggesting there was an interaction between the knowledgeability and the existence of numerals. In the second experiment, we slightly changed the experiment design: we added 8 exposure trials in each contextual numerals condition, making the ratio of exposure trials to critical trials increase from 2:1 to 3:1. We expected the change could make the No Numerals vs. With Numerals manipulation more salient and the hypothesized effects stronger. The predicted results were significant. In the third experiment, we adjusted the experiment materials to remove a potential confounding factor. In the first and second experiment, we had some large numbers in the fillers (e.g., "Robert needs to check whether 12 windows are closed."), whereas in the target trials the numbers were all three (e.g., "Zach needs to check whether 3 of the tickets have won"). This difference between "large numbers" vs. "small numbers" could be a confounding factor. Thus, in the third experiment, we changed all the numbers in the fillers to 3, 4 or 5, in order to ensure that the predicted interaction results from the existence/absence of the numerals rather than the difference between “large numbers” and “small numbers”. The predicted interaction was not significant, but the main effect of numerals was significant. We thought this could result from the fact that there were still numerals in the “no numerals” condition to indicate the total number of the items (e.g., “Zach needs to check whether 3 of the tickets have won.”). In the fourth experiment, we changed the experiment materials to remove this potential confounding factor: we got rid of the numerals in the materials in the “no-numerals” condition and instead used pictures to indicate the total number of the items and how many of them the character has checked. In addition, we got rid of all the exposure trials and kept only the critical trials. We expected the picture version could show the predicted effects without the more salient manipulation brought about by the exposure trials. But the predicted effects were not significant.  We concluded that fillers are needed in order to see the main effect of "some" for partial knowledge vs. full knowledge.  Thus, in this current study, we added back all the exposure trials. Also, we adjusted the critical trials so that they were all identical across the two conditions. We now just have the critical trials (all without number words) within our two sets of exposure trials.

registration_responses.q16.question:
We manipulate the speaker's knowledgeability and the existence of contextual numerals. 
The variable "knowledgeability" is within subject and has 2 levels: partial knowledge or full knowledge. The variable "contextual numeral" is between subject and has 2 levels: with numerals and no numerals.
Each participant will receive 8 target trials (4 partial knowledge + 4 full knowledge) and 24 exposure trials (12 partial knowledge + 12 full knowledge ).
Half of the participants will receive exposure trials with numerals, and the other half will receive exposure trials with no numerals.

More details: 

Each trial given to the participant is composed of three parts: a picture, a short paragraph of text, and three questions. 
An example critical trial is given as follows.
First, a picture is shown to the participant. The picture consists of a character and 3 objects. In the full knowledge condition, 3 of the 3 objects are circled.
Then, a paragraph of text follows the picture. The text first names the speaker and describes the objects and the relevant property: “Letters to Laura's company almost always have checks inside. Today Laura needs to find out whether the above letters have checks inside.” 
Then it is followed by a speech act in which the speaker both declares the (sub)set of the objects he or she has observed and states that some objects have the property: “While pointing to the circled set of letters, Laura tells you, ‘I have now checked these letters and given what I saw, I can tell you that some of today's letters have checks inside.’ ” 
Last, the question phase consists of three questions. The function of the first two questions is to confirm the participant has read the materials carefully and fully understood what is going on in the given scenario. Thus, the first two questions have correct answers. For example: “Did Laura look at all of today's letters?” (correct answer: yes) “Did Laura say that some of today's letters have checks inside?” (correct answer: yes) The third question asks the participant the likelihood of all the objects having the property. The answer to this question is the dependent factor we would analyze. “Assuming that the speaker is providing an accurate description of his/her knowledge, how likely is it that all of today's letters have checks inside? Please provide a probability percentage: ____%”

How we manipulate the speaker’s knowledgeability: 
In the “full knowledge” trials,  x of the x objects are circled in the picture and the speaker says she has checked “these ...(objects)”, while pointing to the circled set of ...(objects). 
In the “partial knowledge” trials, y of the x objects (y
registration_responses.q17.question:
What we will examine is listeners’ interpretation of a statement in which "some" may or may not trigger scalar implicature. The critical question will be "Assuming that the speaker is providing an accurate description of his/her knowledge, how likely is it that all of xxx (items) have the yyy (property)? Please provide a probability percentage: __%" 
This dependent variable ranges from 0% to 100%. If a listener responds with a lower percentage, they are more committed to the “some but not all” reading of “some”, whereas if they respond with a higher percentage, they are more committed to the “some and possibly all” reading by (partially) cancelling the standard implicature of “some”.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Effects of speaker’s perceptual access ("knowledgeability") and contextual numerals on probability ratings will be assessed via linear mixed-effects regression using the lme4 package in R (Bates, Maechler, Bolker, & Walker, 2014).
The predictors are "knowledgeability" and "contextual numeral", as well as their interaction. The dependent variable is the rating of the likelihood of all the items having the property (participants' interpretation of scalar implicature).

q1.value: Battered Child Syndrome: The Role of Expert Testimony in Adolescent Parricide Cases

q3.value: Henry Kempe and colleagues first introduced the term battered child syndrome in 1962. Children suffered multiple forms of abuse before Kempes work, yet medical professionals and politicians were ignorant of the issue. Defense attorneys and prosecuting attorneys adopted the term for different legal reasons, including the use of battered child syndrome (BCS) evidence to prove child abuse, and, alternatively, as a self-defense claim in cases where children killed their abusive parents (i.e., adolescent parricide), presumably in self-defense. Thus, the criminal law pertaining to children accused of patricide was ripe for developments in self-defense law that came with the emergence of the then new, battered woman syndrome (Walker, 1984). As in BWS cases, defense attorneys commonly introduce BCS evidence to satisfy the element of imminent harm in self-defense claims (State v. Young, 1991; State v. Gachot, 1992; State v. Janes, 1993). Specifically, some courts allow the admittance of BCS testimony to assist the trier of fact in determining whether the belief in imminent harm was reasonable. When battered children kill their parents in a non-confrontational manner, defense attorneys proffer BCS testimony to demonstrate how years of abuse can distort childrens perceptions in two ways: through increased arousal (i.e., hypervigilance) and through re-traumatization (e.g., recurring, stressful dreams of the event) (Goldman, 1994). Thus, expert testimony can help explain why a child reasonably believed she or he was in danger and needed to use deadly force even in the absence of an immediate threat to her or himself (Goldman, 1994). Although BWS evidence is widely accepted as a self-defense claim, BCS evidence has had limited success. Instead of questioning whether BCS evidence should be admitted into evidence, the current project questions how jurors respond to BCS evidence, specifically in cases involving adolescent parricide. Will BCS testimony result in verdicts that are more lenient? Could this effect depend on various characteristics of the case? While initial research concerning the influence of BWS expert testimony evidence on guilty verdicts revealed few differences in verdict choices between the presence and absence of BWS testimony (Finkel, Meister, & Lightfoot, 1991; Kasian, Spanos, Terrance, & Peebles, 1993), subsequent investigations demonstrated an increased likelihood of lenient rulings when expert witnesses offer BWS testimony (Terrance, Plumm, & Rhyner, 2012). This research shows that different types of testimony may be more successful for self-defense pleas than are other types and that evaluator gender may moderate this effect (Plumm & Terrance, 2009; Terrance, Plumm, & Rhyner, 2012). The purpose of the current research proposal is to extend the findings for BWS expert testimony to BCS expert testimony. The proposed study will manipulate the presence of expert testimony along with various case factors (i.e., context of the killing, fact pattern orientation, threat inductions). Additionally, this study will explore how participants endorsement of system justification beliefs influence the effect of expert testimony on verdict judgments.

q4.value:
1.	a main effect for expert testimony, such that any testimony will result in more lenient verdicts than no expert testimony. 
2.	a main effect for delay, such that participants who read about a killing directly after a confrontation will render more lenient verdicts than participants who read about a killing that occurred sometime after a confrontation. 
3.	a main effect for threat, such that participants who feel threatened will render more guilty verdicts than participants who do not feel threatened. 
4.	a main effect for fact pattern, such that participants who read a pro-defense fact pattern will render more lenient verdicts than participants who read a pro-prosecution fact pattern. 
5.	a two-way interaction between testimony and delay, such that participants will utilize testimony more when there is a delayed killing.
6.	a two-way interaction between testimony and fact pattern, such that participants will utilize testimony more when they are in the pro-prosecution fact pattern. 
7.	a two-way interaction between delay and fact pattern, such that participants will give the most lenient verdicts in the no delay, pro-defense fact pattern, whereas participants will render the most guilty verdicts in the delay, pro-prosecution fact pattern.  
8.	a three-way interaction between delay, fact pattern, and testimony, such that expert testimony will increase the congruency between the verdicts for those in the delay, pro-prosecution scenario and those in the no delay, pro-defense scenario.  
9.	a three-way interaction between delay, fact pattern, and threat, such that threatened participants will render more guilty verdicts in the delay, pro-prosecution fact pattern as compared to the no delay, pro-defense fact pattern.   
10.	There are two mediation hypotheses (See Figure 1):
a.	For delay, fact pattern, and testimony three-way interaction, self-defense elements (e.g., imminent danger and reasonable force) will mediate the effect of the delay by fact pattern interaction on verdicts. 
b.	For delay, fact pattern, and threat three-way interaction, and for those high in  system justification beliefs (e.g., legitimacy in the criminal justice system), increased perceptions of the defendant as a predator will mediate the effect of the delay by fact pattern interaction on verdicts.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Fact Pattern: Pro-defense vs Pro-prosecution
Timing of Killing: Delay vs No Delay 
Threat Experience: Threat vs No Threat
Expert Testimony: Battered Child Syndrome vs Social Agency vs No Testimony (control)

Verdict Ratings - Overall and Certainty 
Case Perceptions - Self-defense elements, heinousness of crimes, etc. 
System Justification Beliefs
Juvenile super predator Beliefs 
Expert testimony evaluations
Demographics

System justification beliefs scale (Kay & Jost, 2003), juvenile predatory beliefs scale (modified from Juvenile Offender Stereotype Scale, JOSS) (Haegerich & Bottoms, 2002; Haegerich, Salerno, & Bottoms, 2013), case perceptions (Holloway & Wiener, 2018), and expert testimony scale (Schuller et al., 2004).

I will perform a factorial ANOVA for the independent variables on dependent measures for all main effects and interactions, including verdict certainty, case perceptions, system justification beliefs, and juvenile predatory stereotypes. Exploratory mediation and moderation analyses will be performed through Process or through Mplus statistical software.

q20.value: We will transform any data that is severely non-normal and requiring further transformation.

q21.value: We will use two-tailed p-value tests and confidence intervals for inference criteria.

q22.value: Participants who take too little time (less than 2 SD below the average time) or too long time (more than 2 SD above the average time) will be excluded. Participants who fail too many attention checks will also be excluded.

attributes.title: How kids learn that "some" means not all, but "dax" doesn't (SSI)

q1.value: How kids learn that "some" means not all, but "dax" doesn't (SSI)

q4.value:
Experiment 1 is a replication of a finding discovered through exploratory analyses of a different study. Experiment 1 serves as a preregistered replication (with slight modification) of that previous study. In the previous study, Feiman and Barner used a “Give a Quantifier” task, asking children to give “a”, “all”, “every”, “each”, “some” or “dax” of the small toy objects in front of them. We found that children below age 6 gave random quantities for “some” and “dax” – anywhere from 1 to 5 toys. However, while 6- and 7-year-old children gave 2, 3 or 4 fish, they avoided giving 1 or 5 when asked for “some”, but not when asked for “dax”, suggesting that they treated “all” and “a” as alternatives to “some”, but did not think of “dax” as having the same alternatives.

In Experiment 1, we eliminate the "each" and "every" quantifiers from the other experiment, testing only "a", "all", "some" and "dax", to ask whether 6- and 7-year-olds, but not younger children will assume that a request for "some" implies a request to give neither all (i.e. 5) of the objects, nor to give /a/ (i.e. 1) of them, while a request for "dax" does not similarly imply anything.

In Experiment 2, we ask whether having “all” as a lexically stored alternative to “some” is sufficient for children to draw this implicature, or whether they also require the alternatives to be present in the experimental context itself. While Experiment 1 contains the relevant lexical alternatives on other trials (“a” and “all”), Experiment 2 replaces these with a different pair of alternatives (“two” and “three”). We test the same question, given this manipulation -- will older, but not younger, children treat "some" as implying /not all/ and /not a/, and correspondingly, avoid giving 1 and 5, even as they never hear "all" or "a" used for requests on any other trials. We again expect an age difference between 6+ and younger kids, as well as a difference in children's rates of avoiding giving 1 and 5 when asked for "some", but not when asked for "dax".

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Procedure:
Experiment 1: Children will be given five toy fish, five toy sheep, and five toy fruit, and be asked if they know what each kind of toy is called. If they did not, they will be told and asked to repeat the label. The experimenter will put out a plate, and introduce a puppet, Elmo. Children will be told that Elmo would ask them for different things, and to give him what he asks for by putting things on the red plate in front of him. To keep the experiment lively, the experimenter will alternate between asking for objects in an Elmo voice, and having Elmo “whisper” in the experimenter’s ear, so the experimenter would then relay the request to the child. Whether Elmo or the experimenter are saying it, children will always be asked to give objects in the same frame: Can you give Elmo  fruit/sheep/fish? On each trial, the determiner is one of the following: some, dax, a, and all.

Experiment 2: Identical to Experiment 1, except the determiner will be one of the following: some, dax, two, and three

Variables:
This is a mixed design, involving both between and within subject variables.

Between subjects:
-  Alternative Requests: whether the other requests made in the study are "a" and "all", or "two" and "three" is between subjects. This is the comparison between Experiments 1 and 2
- Age: The child's age in years and months; we aim to recruit groups with N=20 children per year between ages 3 and 7, but we will treat Age as a continuous variable (months;days) in the analysis itself.

Within-subjects:
- Quantifier: Whether the request made is for "dax" or "some"

q9.value:
Between subjects counterbalancing: The questions presented to subjects will be ordered according to one of six pseudo-randomized lists, with the constraint that each list has a different quantifier presented first. Children will be randomly assigned to list.
Within-subject counterbalancing: Within each list, the same quantifier is used 4 times in "blocks", with each block containing all 4 quantifiers, for a total of 16 trials. The order of quantifiers, as well as which type of toy is paired with the quantifier is counterbalanced across blocks.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: Children will be recruited from the greater Providence area through family outreach and visits to daycares, schools, summer camps, and the Providence Children's Museum. All procedures have been approved by the Brown University IRB. Parents fill out consent forms on behalf of their children, and all children provide assent to participate. Children aged 7 and older are read an assent form and are asked to sign if willing and able.

q13.value: We plan to collect the same sample size of 100 total unique participants in each experiment.
