question.value:
Which of toys the child is being asked to give.
In Experiment 1, quantifiers include: "some", "dax", "all", "a".
In Experiment 2, quantifiers include: "some", "dax", "two", "three".

The number of toys children give as a result of the determiner used within the statement: Can you give Elmo  fruit/sheep/fish?
We will also measure children's age as a predictor

We will first analyze the results of Experiment 1 and the results of Experiment 2 separately from each other. We will then compare Experiment 1 to Experiment 2, as described below.

Experiment 1
Step 1: Manipulation (sanity) checks
Independent of the analyses of theoretical interest described below (concerning the difference between "some" and "dax"), we want sanity checks on the other quantifiers ("all" and "a" in Exp 1., "two" and "three" in Exp 2). I.e. we want to make sure that kids are understanding what they’re being asked to do on the task in general, across all ages.

So, for “All”, we want to check whether kids give 5/5 at all ages.

Step 1, Analysis 1
“All”
Data: Only “All” trials
DV: Binary: 1 if giving 5/5; 0 if giving anything else
Random IV:  Intercept by subject
Fixed IVs: Age (Continuous) + Intercept
Type of analysis: Logistic Regression

Step 1, Analysis 2
“A”
Data: Only “A” trials 
DV: Binary: 1 if giving 1/5; 0 if giving anything else
Fixed IVs: Age (Continuous) + Intercept 
Random IV:  Intercept by subject
Type of analysis: Logistic Regression

For both of these analyses, based on prior work (our own previous experiment, as well as, e.g. Barner, Chow, Yang (2009), we expect Age to not be significant, and the intercept to be highly significant -- i.e. across ages, all kids should be getting it right. If we do find an effect of age, we will follow up with a Johnson-Neyman analysis to see if there is an age range where the intercept is not significant. This would give us an age at which kids fail, and a boundary age, after which they succeed.

One reasonable possibility is to restrict subsequent analyses of whether kids avoid giving, e.g. 5/5 for “some” or for “dax”, only to those kids who do give 5/5 when asked to give “all” (since, theoretically, they should be avoiding giving 5/5 for “some” due to competition with “all”). However, excluding such children threatens  the validity of our age estimate. If, e.g. younger kids do understand the meaning of “all”, but are just individually noisier givers than older kids in general, by excluding such kids we would have a priori prevented ourselves from finding any average difference between their responses to “some” and “dax” at that younger age. We therefore will not exclude any children in subsequent analyses on the basis of incorrect responding to “all” or “a”.

Step 2: looking for a difference between Some and Dax
Step 2, Analysis 1
The question of theoretical interest in Experiment 1 is whether children give 1 object out of 5 (1/5), 5 objects out of 5 (5/5), or else some other number (2/5, 3/5, or 4/5) in response to different prompts. Although the amounts of objects children can give are inherently physically ordered (giving 2 is more than giving 1 and less than giving 4 or 5), we do not have any theoretical reason to think that children’s responses would be ordered in the same way. That is, we don’t think that giving 1/5 is in any way ‘closer’ to giving the next number up, 2/5, than it is to giving some other number like 4/5 or 5/5. Therefore, we treat the dependent variable in Experiment 1 as categorical rather than ordinal, with three mutually exclusive categories: giving 1/5, giving 5/5, or giving anything else (2/5, 3/5, or 4/5).

The basic analytic approach is therefore multinomial logistic regression, with the DV coded into 3 categories, (1/5, 5/5, or anything else), as above. We code “giving anything else” as the reference level, and so compare two DVs: the rate of giving 1/5 more than the ‘anything else’ category, and the rate of giving 5/5 more than the ‘anything else’ category.

Data: Only the "Some" and "Dax" trials.
Fixed IVs: Age (continuous) * Quantifier (2 levels: Some vs. Dax)
Random IVs: (1) Subject intercept; (2) random slope of Quantifier by subject; (3) correlation between the two. If this maximal model converges, great; if not, remove correlation between the two variables; If still no convergence, remove random slope of Quantifier by subject. (this follows the maximal-first recommendation from Barr, et al., 2013)
DVs: Multinomial (ternary, categorical with 3 levels): giving 1/5, giving 5/5, or giving anything else (2/5, 3/5, or 4/5)
Type of analysis: Multinomial Logistic Regression

-------
The overall model specification in GLMER syntax here is:

HowManyGiven ~ Age * Quantifier + (Quantifier|Subject)


Step 2, Analysis 2+
The second analysis is contingent on there being a significant interaction in Analysis 1 of this step (Step 2). In the case that there is, we will run the corresponding Johnson-Neyman analysis to pinpoint the age at which children begin to differentiate "some" trials from "dax" trials. Note that this is contingent on the availability of adaptations of Johnson-Neyman to multinomial regression, of which we are at present uncertain. If no such adaptation exists, we will run Johnson-Neyman on two separate logistic regressions, coding two separate DVs (giving 1/5 vs. anything else; giving 5/5 vs. anything else).

Step 2, Analysis 3
The third analysis will look at the correlation between the rate of 1/5 and 5/5 responses as a dependent variable, with Quantifier and Age as IVs. We still need to figure out a good way to implement this analysis.

On many different accounts, acquiring "a" as an alternative and acquiring "all" as an alternative should be fairly independent from each other. However, a dependency between them would be predicted by a model where the limiting factor is not knowing the individual alternatives, but a common ability to derive scalar implicatures (relative to either alternative). This analysis is of lesser importance because we may not have the power to estimate whether the effects of the IVs on the two DVs is correlated, and the effect of the IVs on each DV is independently interpretable regardless of whether there is sufficient power to look for this correlation.

Step 3: looking at the simple effects within each quantifier request
This step is contingent on there being either a significant effect of Quantifier, or a significant interaction of Quantifier by Age (or both) in Step 2. This analysis looks at the ‘simple effects’ -- whether kids avoid giving 5/5 and 1/5 relative to anything else within each quantifier separately, and whether there is an effect of age within each quantifier.

There is one major notable difference between the analyses in Step 2 and Step 3. In Step 2, we do not care about the baseline rate of giving ‘anything else’ – we only care about whether it is different in response to requests for “some” than for “dax”. However, in Step 3, we do care about the specific rates – we want to know whether kids give 5/5 less than, e.g. 2/5 or 3/5. This means that we can’t simply group all of the ‘anything else’ trials into a single outcome, since we’d predict triple the number of responses summing across 2/5, 3/5 and 4/5 than we would expect for each of these responses separately.

We will consider two approaches to this problem, depending on which works with the assumptions of multinomial regression. The first and conceptually ideal option is to divide all responses of 2/5, 3/5 and 4/5 by 3, while still grouping the three types of responses into a single category. Effectively, each such responses would weigh 1/3 as much as a responses of 5/5. However, we are not sure at present whether a multinomial regression allows this kind of coding scheme for the DVs. In the case that it doesn’t, we will solve this problem just by coding every level of the DV into a separate category, creating a 5-level DV. We would then run these models twice: once with giving 5/5 coded as the reference level, and once with 1/5 coded as the reference level, and compare these to each other response individually.

Analyses 1 and 2
Whatever the approach taken above, the rest is the same. Analyses 1 and 2 will be two separate but identical multinomial regressions, one for just “some” trials, and one for just “dax” trials.

Analysis 3+
Finally, contingent on there being significant effects of age, up to four separate analyses will look at the age at which the effect becomes significantly different from zero, using the Johnson-Neyman technique. This will use 2 analyses over each multinomial regression, if possible. However, if there is no implementation of J-N for multinomial regressions, we will use up to 4 separate logistic regressions, for 2 levels of the Quantifier IV (“some”; “dax”) by the 2 DVs of interests (1/5 vs. anything else; 5/5 vs. anything else)

Experiment 2
Step 1: Manipulation (sanity) checks
First, we want to do the same manipulation checks on kids’ giving in response to requests for “two” and “three” as we did for “a” and “all” in Experiment 1. Note, however, that the prediction here is different – we do not necessarily expect all 3-year-olds to be ‘2-knowers’ or ‘3-knowers’, per much existing literature on the Give-a-Number task.

Step 1, Analysis 1
“Two”
Data: Only “Two” trials
DV: Binary: 1 if giving 2/5; 0 if giving anything else
Random IV:  Intercept by subject
Fixed IVs: Age (Continuous) + Intercept
Type of analysis: Logistic Regression

Step 1, Analysis 2
“Three”
Data: Only “Three” trials 
DV: Binary: 1 if giving 3/5; 0 if giving anything else
Fixed IVs: Age (Continuous) + Intercept 
Random IV:  Intercept by subject
Type of analysis: Logistic Regression

Step 2: looking for a difference between Some and Dax
We use the same general approach in this experiment, with one significant modification: instead of always lumping 2/5, 3/5 and 4/5 responses into a single category of ‘giving anything else’, we are going to use multiple different coding schemes of this DV to answer different questions. The model specification is the same in all of these cases:

HowManyGiven ~ Age * Quantifier + (Quantifier|Subject)

What changes is how the ‘HowManyGiven’ variable is coded.

Step 2, Analysis 1
One question is the same as in Experiment 1 – do kids avoid giving 1/5 and 5/5 when asked for “some” more than for “Dax”, and whether this interacts with Age. However, we can no longer use the same ternary coding scheme as before, of 1/5, 5/5, or anything else, because the ‘anything else’ category includes 2/5 and 3/5, which might themselves be avoided due to competition with the other requests. The only really meaningful comparison to a ‘baseline’ is to 4/5.

Another, related question is whether children avoid giving the correct responses for the mentioned alternatives (2/5 and 3/5) relative to a response that is never mentioned (4/5).

We try to answer both of these questions with a single analysis. We treat each possible response as a separate level of our categorical DV. In total, this means there are now 5 levels of the categorical DV – one for each number given. The only response that we theoretically expect to be a ‘baseline’ is giving 4/5, since this is neither one of the mentioned alternative requests (“two”, “three”), nor one of the hypothesized scalar alternatives (“a”, “all”). We therefore code giving 4/5 as the baseline reference level of the DV, and compare all other responses to this baseline.

Our Quantifier IV is the same as before – we care about the difference between “Some” and “Dax”, but we now care about it relative to 4 different DVs – the rates of giving each of 1/5, 2/5, 3/5, and 5/5, relative to the rate of giving 4/5.

Step 2, Analysis 2
We also want to know whether children avoid giving both of 1/5 and 5/5 more than both 2/5 and 3/5 (again for “some”, more than for “dax”, again interacting with Age). For this analysis we exclude trials where children gave 4/5, and run a logistic regression with just one binary DV: coding giving 1/5 and 5/5 as 1 and coding giving 2/5 and 3/5 as 0.

If there is a significant difference, we may also want to look at each of the 5/5 and 1/5 responses individually, relative to both 2/5 and 3/5 lumped together (as in Step 3 of Experiment 1).

Step 2, Analysis 3+
As in Experiment 1, wherever there are significant interactions between Quantifier and Age, we will want to run a Johnson-Neyman analysis on the same regression models to identify the age at which the number of objects children give begins to depend on whether they were asked to give “some” or “dax”.

Step 3: looking at the simple effects within each quantifier
As in Experiment 1, this step is contingent on there being either a significant effect of Quantifier, or a significant interaction of Quantifier by Age (or both) in Step 2. This analysis looks at the ‘simple effects’: whether kids avoid giving 5/5 and 1/5 – and now also 2/5 and 3/5 -- relative to 4/5 within each quantifier separately, and whether there is an effect of age within each quantifier.

Since we care about exactly the same DVs as in Step 2, we will simply repeat all of the 3 analyses in Step 2 separately for “some” and for “dax” trials. The issue with a baseline no longer arises, since we are coding each number given separately, into a 5-level DV (in Analysis 1 and into a simple binary DV (using a binary logistic regression) in Analysis 2. Analysis 3 will again apply Johnson-Neyman to whichever effects are significant (as in Experiment 1), comparing the baseline of no differences between the rates of giving different quantities of objects.

Comparing Experiment 1 and Experiment 2
Step 1: We want to know if the number of toys children gave in response to requests for “some” and for “dax” differed depending on the Experiment, both relative to each other, and in absolute terms.

DVs: To make the experiments comparable, we will use the same coding scheme as in Experiment 1 alone: a ternary DV: giving 1/5, 5/5, or anything else. This again leads to using a multinomial regression.

Analysis 1: Omnibus comparison of Q * Exp * Age
We first ask whether “some” and “dax” differ relative to each other. We select just the data from the “some” and “dax” trials, from both Experiments.

IVs: The fixed effects of interest here are Quantifier (“some” or “dax”), Experiment (1 or 2), and Age, and the full set of interaction terms. If the presence of different alternative requests (in Exp 1 vs 2) makes a difference to children’s giving behavior, we expect that to be the case at older, but not younger ages. In other words, on this hypothesis we expect a 3-way interaction. On the alternative hypothesis, where the presence of alternative requests doesn’t make a difference, we expect no interactions or effects involving Exp 1 vs. 2, but the same interaction of Age with Quantifier as we would see in Exps 1 and 2 alone.

Analyses 2 and 3: Simple effects of each Quantifier
Here we ask whether children’s giving behavior on “some” requests alone, and on “dax” requests alone differs depending on the Experiment. We break down the analysis above into two identical analyses, one for “dax” and one for “some”. This means removing the effect of Quantifier from the IVs, so that the IV specification is now Experiment * Age.

registration_responses.q1: How kids learn that "some" means not all, but "dax" doesn't (SSI)
registration_responses.q4:
Experiment 1 is a replication of a finding discovered through exploratory analyses of a different study. Experiment 1 serves as a preregistered replication (with slight modification) of that previous study. In the previous study, Feiman and Barner used a “Give a Quantifier” task, asking children to give “a”, “all”, “every”, “each”, “some” or “dax” of the small toy objects in front of them. We found that children below age 6 gave random quantities for “some” and “dax” – anywhere from 1 to 5 toys. However, while 6- and 7-year-old children gave 2, 3 or 4 fish, they avoided giving 1 or 5 when asked for “some”, but not when asked for “dax”, suggesting that they treated “all” and “a” as alternatives to “some”, but did not think of “dax” as having the same alternatives.

In Experiment 1, we eliminate the "each" and "every" quantifiers from the other experiment, testing only "a", "all", "some" and "dax", to ask whether 6- and 7-year-olds, but not younger children will assume that a request for "some" implies a request to give neither all (i.e. 5) of the objects, nor to give /a/ (i.e. 1) of them, while a request for "dax" does not similarly imply anything.

In Experiment 2, we ask whether having “all” as a lexically stored alternative to “some” is sufficient for children to draw this implicature, or whether they also require the alternatives to be present in the experimental context itself. While Experiment 1 contains the relevant lexical alternatives on other trials (“a” and “all”), Experiment 2 replaces these with a different pair of alternatives (“two” and “three”). We test the same question, given this manipulation -- will older, but not younger, children treat "some" as implying /not all/ and /not a/, and correspondingly, avoid giving 1 and 5, even as they never hear "all" or "a" used for requests on any other trials. We again expect an age difference between 6+ and younger kids, as well as a difference in children's rates of avoiding giving 1 and 5 when asked for "some", but not when asked for "dax".

Between subjects counterbalancing: The questions presented to subjects will be ordered according to one of six pseudo-randomized lists, with the constraint that each list has a different quantifier presented first. Children will be randomly assigned to list.
Within-subject counterbalancing: Within each list, the same quantifier is used 4 times in "blocks", with each block containing all 4 quantifiers, for a total of 16 trials. The order of quantifiers, as well as which type of toy is paired with the quantifier is counterbalanced across blocks.

registration_responses.q8.question:
Procedure:
Experiment 1: Children will be given five toy fish, five toy sheep, and five toy fruit, and be asked if they know what each kind of toy is called. If they did not, they will be told and asked to repeat the label. The experimenter will put out a plate, and introduce a puppet, Elmo. Children will be told that Elmo would ask them for different things, and to give him what he asks for by putting things on the red plate in front of him. To keep the experiment lively, the experimenter will alternate between asking for objects in an Elmo voice, and having Elmo “whisper” in the experimenter’s ear, so the experimenter would then relay the request to the child. Whether Elmo or the experimenter are saying it, children will always be asked to give objects in the same frame: Can you give Elmo  fruit/sheep/fish? On each trial, the determiner is one of the following: some, dax, a, and all.

Experiment 2: Identical to Experiment 1, except the determiner will be one of the following: some, dax, two, and three

Variables:
This is a mixed design, involving both between and within subject variables.

Between subjects:
-  Alternative Requests: whether the other requests made in the study are "a" and "all", or "two" and "three" is between subjects. This is the comparison between Experiments 1 and 2
- Age: The child's age in years and months; we aim to recruit groups with N=20 children per year between ages 3 and 7, but we will treat Age as a continuous variable (months;days) in the analysis itself.

Within-subjects:
- Quantifier: Whether the request made is for "dax" or "some"
registration_responses.q12.question: Children will be recruited from the greater Providence area through family outreach and visits to daycares, schools, summer camps, and the Providence Children's Museum. All procedures have been approved by the Brown University IRB. Parents fill out consent forms on behalf of their children, and all children provide assent to participate. Children aged 7 and older are read an assent form and are asked to sign if willing and able.

Effectively, each such responses would weigh 1/3 as much as a responses of 5/5. However, we are not sure at present whether a multinomial regression allows this kind of coding scheme for the DVs. In the case that it doesn’t, we will solve this problem just by coding every level of the DV into a separate category, creating a 5-level DV. We would then run these models twice: once with giving 5/5 coded as the reference level, and once with 1/5 coded as the reference level, and compare these to each other response individually.

Analyses 1 and 2
Whatever the approach taken above, the rest is the same. Analyses 1 and 2 will be two separate but identical multinomial regressions, one for just “some” trials, and one for just “dax” trials.

Analysis 3+
Finally, contingent on there being significant effects of age, up to four separate analyses will look at the age at which the effect becomes significantly different from zero, using the Johnson-Neyman technique. This will use 2 analyses over each multinomial regression, if possible. However, if there is no implementation of J-N for multinomial regressions, we will use up to 4 separate logistic regressions, for 2 levels of the Quantifier IV (“some”; “dax”) by the 2 DVs of interests (1/5 vs. anything else; 5/5 vs. anything else)

Experiment 2
Step 1: Manipulation (sanity) checks
First, we want to do the same manipulation checks on kids’ giving in response to requests for “two” and “three” as we did for “a” and “all” in Experiment 1. Note, however, that the prediction here is different – we do not necessarily expect all 3-year-olds to be ‘2-knowers’ or ‘3-knowers’, per much existing literature on the Give-a-Number task.

Step 1, Analysis 1
“Two”
Data: Only “Two” trials
DV: Binary: 1 if giving 2/5; 0 if giving anything else
Random IV:  Intercept by subject
Fixed IVs: Age (Continuous) + Intercept
Type of analysis: Logistic Regression

Step 1, Analysis 2
“Three”
Data: Only “Three” trials 
DV: Binary: 1 if giving 3/5; 0 if giving anything else
Fixed IVs: Age (Continuous) + Intercept 
Random IV:  Intercept by subject
Type of analysis: Logistic Regression

Step 2: looking for a difference between Some and Dax
We use the same general approach in this experiment, with one significant modification: instead of always lumping 2/5, 3/5 and 4/5 responses into a single category of ‘giving anything else’, we are going to use multiple different coding schemes of this DV to answer different questions. The model specification is the same in all of these cases:

HowManyGiven ~ Age * Quantifier + (Quantifier|Subject)

What changes is how the ‘HowManyGiven’ variable is coded.

Step 2, Analysis 1
One question is the same as in Experiment 1 – do kids avoid giving 1/5 and 5/5 when asked for “some” more than for “Dax”, and whether this interacts with Age. However, we can no longer use the same ternary coding scheme as before, of 1/5, 5/5, or anything else, because the ‘anything else’ category includes 2/5 and 3/5, which might themselves be avoided due to competition with the other requests. The only really meaningful comparison to a ‘baseline’ is to 4/5.

Another, related question is whether children avoid giving the correct responses for the mentioned alternatives (2/5 and 3/5) relative to a response that is never mentioned (4/5).

We try to answer both of these questions with a single analysis. We treat each possible response as a separate level of our categorical DV. In total, this means there are now 5 levels of the categorical DV – one for each number given. The only response that we theoretically expect to be a ‘baseline’ is giving 4/5, since this is neither one of the mentioned alternative requests (“two”, “three”), nor one of the hypothesized scalar alternatives (“a”, “all”). We therefore code giving 4/5 as the baseline reference level of the DV, and compare all other responses to this baseline.

Our Quantifier IV is the same as before – we care about the difference between “Some” and “Dax”, but we now care about it relative to 4 different DVs – the rates of giving each of 1/5, 2/5, 3/5, and 5/5, relative to the rate of giving 4/5.

Step 2, Analysis 2
We also want to know whether children avoid giving both of 1/5 and 5/5 more than both 2/5 and 3/5 (again for “some”, more than for “dax”, again interacting with Age). For this analysis we exclude trials where children gave 4/5, and run a logistic regression with just one binary DV: coding giving 1/5 and 5/5 as 1 and coding giving 2/5 and 3/5 as 0.

If there is a significant difference, we may also want to look at each of the 5/5 and 1/5 responses individually, relative to both 2/5 and 3/5 lumped together (as in Step 3 of Experiment 1).

Step 2, Analysis 3+
As in Experiment 1, wherever there are significant interactions between Quantifier and Age, we will want to run a Johnson-Neyman analysis on the same regression models to identify the age at which the number of objects children give begins to depend on whether they were asked to give “some” or “dax”.

Step 3: looking at the simple effects within each quantifier
As in Experiment 1, this step is contingent on there being either a significant effect of Quantifier, or a significant interaction of Quantifier by Age (or both) in Step 2. This analysis looks at the ‘simple effects’: whether kids avoid giving 5/5 and 1/5 – and now also 2/5 and 3/5 -- relative to 4/5 within each quantifier separately, and whether there is an effect of age within each quantifier.

Since we care about exactly the same DVs as in Step 2, we will simply repeat all of the 3 analyses in Step 2 separately for “some” and for “dax” trials. The issue with a baseline no longer arises, since we are coding each number given separately, into a 5-level DV (in Analysis 1 and into a simple binary DV (using a binary logistic regression) in Analysis 2. Analysis 3 will again apply Johnson-Neyman to whichever effects are significant (as in Experiment 1), comparing the baseline of no differences between the rates of giving different quantities of objects.

Comparing Experiment 1 and Experiment 2
Step 1: We want to know if the number of toys children gave in response to requests for “some” and for “dax” differed depending on the Experiment, both relative to each other, and in absolute terms.

DVs: To make the experiments comparable, we will use the same coding scheme as in Experiment 1 alone: a ternary DV: giving 1/5, 5/5, or anything else. This again leads to using a multinomial regression.

Analysis 1: Omnibus comparison of Q * Exp * Age
We first ask whether “some” and “dax” differ relative to each other. We select just the data from the “some” and “dax” trials, from both Experiments.

IVs: The fixed effects of interest here are Quantifier (“some” or “dax”), Experiment (1 or 2), and Age, and the full set of interaction terms. If the presence of different alternative requests (in Exp 1 vs 2) makes a difference to children’s giving behavior, we expect that to be the case at older, but not younger ages. In other words, on this hypothesis we expect a 3-way interaction. On the alternative hypothesis, where the presence of alternative requests doesn’t make a difference, we expect no interactions or effects involving Exp 1 vs. 2, but the same interaction of Age with Quantifier as we would see in Exps 1 and 2 alone.

Analyses 2 and 3: Simple effects of each Quantifier
Here we ask whether children’s giving behavior on “some” requests alone, and on “dax” requests alone differs depending on the Experiment. We break down the analysis above into two identical analyses, one for “dax” and one for “some”. This means removing the effect of Quantifier from the IVs, so that the IV specification is now Experiment * Age.

attributes.title: Simulation Induced Malleability- Follow Up Studies

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Situational SIM: Exploring the effect of simulating situations on simulation-induced malleability

sample.value: A sample size of 218 was determined to provide 99% power to detect the expected effect, based on a pilot study.

analyses.value:
A two-by-two repeated measures ANOVA will be performed on the data, with type of adjective rated (competent and physical) and type of simulation (neutral or competence) as independent variables and the change in ratings as the dependent variable. 


Our primary hypothesis is that there will be an interaction between the type of adjective rated, and type of simulation, such that rating differences will be greater for the competent than physical in the competent simulation condition, but not in the neutral simulation condition.  We do not have any predictions about the main effect of type of adjective rated or type of simulation. 


We will also conduct a t-test on the simple effect of type of simulation on each type of adjective. We expect to see a simple effect of type of simulation on rating differences for competent adjectives, such that there will be a greater increase in ratings for competent adjectives for the competent than for the neutral simulation. We have no such predictions for the physical adjectives.

outliers.value: Participants who have participated in previous studies on simulation-induced malleability will be excluded from our analyses. Additionally, participants whose overall time on task is too short, participants who self-report poor English comprehension, and participants who provide fewer than 5 unique answers will be removed.

dependent.value:
Our primary dependent variable will be based on the difference between participant self-ratings at the pre-simulation and post-simulation blocks. 


At the start of the study, all participants will rate how well a series of adjectives apply to them on a sliding scale from “not at all” to “extremely,” with the slider at a starting point in the middle. Half of the words will be selected from a list of traits that reflect the trait ‘competence.’ These words will be selected from WordNet synonyms and dictionary synonyms for “competent.” The other half of the words will be words used to describe physical appearance, normed to be neutral on competence. These words are a control condition, as self-reported ratings of physical appearance should not change when a psychological trait is being simulated. 


In the second part of the study, participants will simulate themselves in a series of three situations, pre-rated to either evoke competence or to be emotionally neutral. If they are in the competent condition, they will write about three competent situations, and if in the control condition, to write about neutral situations. Participants will be asked to imagine themselves in each situation, and to write about the experience in detail, in particular how they would feel. They will write for 60 seconds for each situation, after which the survey will automatically advance. 


In the final part of the study, all participants will re-rate themselves on the traits from the first block.


The dependent variable will measure the difference between the first and second self-ratings. If the simulation increases individuals’ perceptions of their ratings on the adjectives, we will see a positive difference between the two time periods.

conditions.value:
Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two conditions. During the simulation block, participants will simulate themselves on a series of either neutral or competent situations. This will create two conditions:

1) Neutral simulation: Participants will be asked to simulate themselves engaging in neutral actions that do not reflect the presence or absence of competence.
2) Competence simulation: Participants will be asked to simulate themselves engaging in competent actions.

hypothesis.value:
How does simulating the self in a situation affect trait-related self-knowledge? We expect that simulating the self engaging in actions that display a certain trait (e.g. competence) will shift self-perceptions on related traits. For example, after simulating oneself engaging in skillful or thoughtful acts, a person’s ratings of traits related to competence will increase. In comparison with other past simulation-induced malleability (SIM) studies, in this study, the self is used as a target for simulation. 


Participants will be recruited through Prolific, where they will rate how well certain traits, selected to be high on competence or physical attributes, apply to them. They will then simulate themselves in three hypothetical situations, pre-rated to be either high in competence or neutrally valanced. Afterwards, participants will again rate how well the adjectives apply to them.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
